I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the Pacific Region 
Infrastructure Facility (PRIF) by continuing to resource the coordination and technical assistance 
activities of the PRIF coordination office for another 4 years, from November 2019 to October 
2023. The TA design is based on review of PRIF’s current phase and consultation with PRIF 
partners.1 Cofinanced by multiple partners, PRIF is an investment coordination and technical 
assistance facility that supports the planning, prioritization, coordination, and management of 
infrastructure  in  the  Pacific.  PRIF  aims  to  improve  development  effectiveness  and  the 
sustainability of infrastructure investments in Pacific island member countries2 by (i) strengthening 
coordination among PRIF partners, (ii) improving infrastructure policies and regulation, and (iii) 
improving infrastructure planning and management. A PRIF management committee provides 
strategic oversight of PRIF activities, based on governance arrangements in the PRIF charter. 
PRIF partners chair the management committee on a rotational basis. The PRIF coordination 
office is located in the Pacific Liaison and Coordination Office of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB). The coordination office supports enhanced coordination and provides short-term TA to 
respond to requests from PRIF partners and member countries.  
 
2.  The TA is consistent with Strategy 2030’s focus on infrastructure as a key development 
priority in its aim to tackle climate change, build disaster resilience, make cities more livable, 
strengthen capacity, and foster regional cooperation and integration.3 The TA is also consistent 
with ADB’s Pacific Approach 2016–2020, with its focus on reducing costs, managing risk, and 
enabling value creation.4 The TA is included in the Pacific regional operations business plan, 
2019–2021 as a 2019 nonlending activity.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  PRIF member countries face several challenges in infrastructure planning, financing and 
management. Member countries are remote and have small populations, precluding economies 
of scale in infrastructure delivery and management. Given their narrow economic base, member 
countries rely heavily on development aid and remittances. They also face frequent natural 
disasters and climate change, resulting in additional unplanned costs. Policy, institutional, and 
capacity  issues  also  negatively  affect  performance  and  sustainability  of  investment. 6 
Infrastructure investment and service delivery in Pacific island countries lag well behind global 
and Asian averages. ADB estimates that the Pacific region requires $3.1 billion annually to fully 
address its infrastructure needs.7 Development partners active in the Pacific have responded to 
the region’s challenges by (i) establishing PRIF in 2008, to provide better coordinated support to 
PRIF member countries, (ii) significantly increasing available finance to Pacific island countries, 
and (iii) providing long-term capacity development. 
 
1  The PRIF partners are the Asian Development Bank (ADB), Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, 
European Union, European Investment Bank, Japan International Cooperation Agency, New Zealand Ministry of 
Foreign Affairs and Trade, United States Department of State, and the World Bank Group. 
2  The 13 PRIF member countries are the Cook Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, Fiji, Kiribati, the Marshall 
Islands, Nauru, Niue, Palau, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu. PRIF does not cover Papua 
New Guinea.

Manila. 
4  ADB. 2016. Pacific Approach 2016–2020. Manila. 
5  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 18 July 2019. 
6  World Bank. 2007. The Pacific Infrastructure Challenge. Washington, DC. 
7  ADB. 2017. Meeting Asia’s Infrastructure Needs. Manila (p. xi).

4.  Some of the key achievements of PRIF since its establishment in 2008 include: (i) 
facilitation of strategic engagement between development partners in the Pacific, (ii) helping 
member countries plan infrastructure investments and maintenance needs, (iii) providing a 
platform for technical experts from PRIF partners in sector working groups to develop common 
approaches to sectoral challenges, (iv) supporting regional organizations such as the Pacific 
Power Association and the Pacific Water and Wastewater Association, (v) leading applied 
research on engineering solutions for local Pacific conditions, and (vi) rapidly mobilizing technical 
resources immediately after disasters.8 While the coordination effort of development partners has 
significantly  improved  over  recent  years,  the  recent  and  proposed  scaling  up  of  financial 
resources by development partners in the Pacific will require ongoing, long-term, and regionally 
focused coordination and support for infrastructure planning, financing and management. 
 
5.  PRIF’s first phase (August 2009–April  2013) comprised a secretariat in the World Bank 
Sydney office and a TA support facility at ADB’s Pacific Liaison and Coordination Office in Sydney. 
The current phase (April 2013–October 2019) is being implemented by the PRIF coordination 
office under a single ADB TA providing secretariat services and TA.9 
 
6.  A 2019 strategic review of the PRIF, commissioned by ADB’s Pacific Department in 2018, 
found PRIF to be an example of best practice in coordination among development partners.10 The 
review  found  that  PRIF’s  activities  have  (i)  reduced  duplication  of  effort,  (ii)  supported 
opportunities for collaboration, (iii) helped identify and scope projects of interest to all PRIF 
partners, and (iv) facilitated a more open and cooperative donor environment. Key lessons from 
this and previous reviews that have guided TA design include: (i) PRIF should strengthen its 
strategic engagement with member countries on upstream infrastructure planning, priority setting, 
financing, and asset management; (ii) the PRIF coordination office should intensify benchmarking 
efforts, including strengthening data on infrastructure in the Pacific and engaging PRIF partners 
on  results;  (iii)  PRIF  partner  coordination  through  sector  working  groups  and  the  PRIF 
management committee should remain a core function of the coordination office; and (iv) PRIF 
partners and the coordination office should continue to support opportunities for greater private 
sector participation alongside individual development partners and the Pacific Private Sector 
Development Initiative.11 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome

investments and service delivery in PRIF member countries improved (footnote 2). The TA will

B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  The TA will continue to support PRIF coordination office activities.13 The outputs of the TA 
are as follows. 
 
9.  Output  1:  Coordination  of  Pacific  Region  Infrastructure  Facility  partner 
infrastructure investments in the Pacific further enhanced. The coordination office will help 
to align and coordinate PRIF partner infrastructure investments in collaboration with member 
countries, PRIF partners, and other regional stakeholders. The coordination office will facilitate 
and  support  PRIF  partners  by (i)  coordinating  strategic  engagement between  partners; (ii) 
preparing and implementing a work plan approved by the PRIF management committee; (iii) 
identifying strategic infrastructure issues; (iv) supporting and facilitating sector and crosscutting 
theme  working  groups;  (v)  facilitating  increased  cofinancing  activities;  (vi)  monitoring  and 
evaluation; and (vii) undertaking communications activities, including a strategy and PRIF website. 
 
10.  Output  2:  Technical  advice  on  infrastructure  development  and  sustainable 
infrastructure management provided to Pacific Region Infrastructure Facility partners and 
member countries. The coordination office will manage the provision of technical advice to PRIF 
partners  and  member  countries  on  (i)  infrastructure  plans  and  planning  frameworks;  (ii) 
infrastructure policy and regulatory advice; (iii) strategies and research on infrastructure sectors 
and crosscutting themes; (iv) project implementation and coordination advice; (v) infrastructure 
management advice, including asset management, maintenance, and budget frameworks; and 
(vi) issues such as performance benchmarking, project scoping, innovative technologies, and 
private sector participation.14 The coordination office may also provide technical advice and 
support on crosscutting themes such as gender, climate change, and disaster risk preparedness 
and response. The coordination office will provide quality assurance of TA support, drawing on 
expertise from PRIF partner sector working group members and specialist short-term technical 
consultants. The TA may also pilot test community-based solutions and local materials, including 
designing, implementing, monitoring, and evaluating the potential to scale up and replicate the 
pilot approaches (para. 17). 
 
11.  It is expected that member countries will continue to improve the quality of their public 
expenditure,  maintain  or  increase  budget  allocation  for  infrastructure  refurbishment  and 
maintenance, use infrastructure planning documents, and continue to demand external advisory 
services.  PRIF  partners  are  expected  to  remain  committed  to  increased  coordination  and 
cofinancing. The major risks are (i) PRIF member country government agencies have limited 
capacity to implement infrastructure plans, (ii) data availability and quality for analyses is poor, (iii) 
PRIF partner commitment to strengthening coordination and cofinancing declines, and (iv) PRIF 
partners do not allocate sufficient resources to accompany coordination office support and TA, or 
for cofinancing and project investment. The TA will mitigate major risks by (i) refining the 
infrastructure planning process to recognize and address capacity constraints, (ii) providing 
capacity development activities alongside TA within the constraints of the TA budget, (iii) helping

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $9.09 million, of which (i) $2.00 million (22.0%) will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund ($1.00 million from TASF 6 and 
$1.00 million from TASF-other sources), (ii) $4.09 million (45.0%) will be financed on a grant basis 
by the Government of Australia, and (iii) $3.00 million (33.0%) will be financed on a grant basis 
by the Government of New Zealand.15 ADB will administer the grants and additional cofinancing 
is anticipated.16 PRIF partners will also explore opportunities to provide in-kind contributions, 
including financing and implementing parallel technical activities and individual consultant roles. 
PRIF member countries will provide counterpart support in the form of country data, office 
accommodation, counterpart staff and other in-kind contributions. The key expenditure items are 
listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will be the executing agency of the TA. ADB’s Pacific Department will administer and 
implement the TA through the PRIF coordination office over 48 months, from 1 November 2019 
to 31 October 2023. It is anticipated that a new phase could be explored in mid-2022 to ensure 
continuity. 
  
14.  ADB  will  engage  consultants  and  procure  nonconsulting  services,  equipment,  and 
materials, following ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its 
associated project administration and staff instructions. ADB will disburse the proceeds of the TA 
in line with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time 
to time). The coordination office will not undertake activities in member countries until no-objection 
letters are obtained. Upon TA completion, ADB will transfer equipment and materials either to 
subsequent phases of PRIF TA or to member countries, as determined by the PRIF management 
committee. Training and workshops will be implemented through consultants’ contracts. The 
implementation arrangements are summarized in the table below.

15.  Consulting services. The TA will require 241 person-months of international consultants, 
119 person-months of national consultants, and the services of consulting firms. ADB will recruit 
up to six full-time consultants—four international (176 person-months) and two national (88 
person-months)—and  one  part-time  national  consultant  (16  person-months)  for  the  PRIF 
coordination office core team using individual consultant selection. The PRIF coordination office 
core team will include a team leader, an infrastructure economist, two technical assistance officers, 
a secretariat and communications coordinator, an operations and finance officer, a part-time 
monitoring and evaluation specialist. The terms of reference for the core consultant team are 
accessible  from  Appendix  3.  Specialist  short-term  consultants  and  consulting  firms  will  be 
recruited to support the coordination office core team and provide technical expertise for on 
demand assignments requested by PRIF partners or member countries. The requirements for 
each type of expertise and the length of engagement will vary according to the scope of work and 
sectoral focus. The specialist individual consultants and firms will be recruited using a combination 
of individual consultant selection, framework agreement assignments, quality- and cost-based 
selection, and consultant’s selection qualification. The coordination office core team will prepare 
the terms of reference for assignments by specialist consultants and firms and submit them for 
endorsement  by  the  PRIF  management  committee  and  ADB  TA  supervising  unit.  Direct 
contracting will be used to contract GHD Limited (GHD NZ) for the future monitoring phase of 
Road Pavement Design and Pavement Trials for the Pacific Region, subject to satisfactory 
performance of the current assignment.17 
 
17 GHD Limited (GHD NZ) was recruited using consultant selection qualification on 15 April 2019 for a contract value 
of $147,022. The estimated value of the potential future assignment is about $200,000. Consistent with the Staff

16.  Work planning and monitoring. The coordination office’s team leader will prepare a 
strategic work plan in close collaboration with the core consulting team and the PRIF management 
committee. The requirements of the strategic workplan will be specified by the management 
committee. The management committee will approve the coordination office’s strategic work plan 
and annual updates. The coordination office will prepare quarterly progress reports and annual 
reports for the management committee in an agreed format, outlining the activities undertaken, 
progress towards targets, alignment with the TA requirements, financial reconciliation, and issues 
or risks. Sector working groups will comprise technical sector specialists from the PRIF partners. 
The lead sector coordinators will guide the coordination office’s sector work. The coordination 
office will prepare a results framework to be approved by the management committee and report 
quarterly and annually against the results framework. The coordination office will conceptualize 
new technical assistance and knowledge activities in collaboration with sector working groups, for 
management committee approval. The coordination office will prepare a tailored dissemination 
plan when conceptualizing each knowledge activity. 
 
17.  Pilot testing. PRIF’s research focus may require pilot testing potential project approaches 
to test local materials, low cost solutions, and other small-scale project approaches. During the 
current phase of the TA, several studies have been prepared that explored new and innovative 
technology, material and approaches that support community-based, local and low cost solutions. 
Some examples where pilot testing could be beneficial include: Road Pavement Design and 
Pavement Trials for the Pacific Region, and Affordable Coastal Protection in the Pacific Islands. 
Pilot testing of the recommendations from these studies would provide the opportunity to scale 
up and include these solutions in PRIF partner and community projects. All pilot testing will be 
agreed  with  the  government  in  a  confirmed  aide-mémoire  or  signed  memorandum  of 
understanding. The proposed pilot testing activities will not result in any potential adverse 
environmental or social impacts.18 
 
18.  Social media and websites. The current PRIF TA developed and maintains a website 
and social media presence.19 The coordination office and a specialist web services firm funded 
by the TA will continue to maintain the website. ADB will negotiate suitable arrangements with 
PRIF partners for maintaining the website and social media after TA completion. 
 
19.  Cofinancier requirements. Consistent with the cofinancing agreements, ADB will provide 
to each cofinancier (i) annual reports on implementation of the TA activities; (ii) unaudited annual 
financial statements showing receipts, income, and expenditures under the TA account after the 
end of each fiscal year; and (iii) a terminal financial statement showing receipts, income, and 
expenditures under the TA and any remaining balance after the TA’s financial closure. ADB’s 
external auditor may undertake audits of annual financial statements at the cofinanciers’ request. 
The cost of external audits will be charged to the TA account and is in the TA’s financing plan.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $4,089,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Government of Australia; (ii) 
ADB administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $3,003,750 
to be financed on a grant basis by the Government of New Zealand; and (iii) ADB providing the 
balance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 on a grant basis for the Pacific Region 
Infrastructure  Facility  Coordination  Office—Leveraging  Infrastructure  for  Sustainable 
Development, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

coordination with PRIF partners (including PRIF partner country post representatives), regional agencies, 
and other regional TA programs (by December 2019). 
1.6  Implement the PRIF coordination and communications strategy, and report to the management 
committee quarterly on progress (quarterly). 
1.7  Prepare a database of proposed PRIF partner pipeline activities (by the end of the first year), and 
update the pipeline (every 6 months). 
1.8  Maintain and update the PRIF website, prepare online newsletters, and manage social media 
(ongoing).

10  Appendix 1 
1.9  Provide secretariat support to all management committee and sector working group meetings 
(ongoing). 
1.10  Support the management committee chair to raise the strategic level of engagement at 
management committee meetings (ongoing). 
1.11  Assist the management committee to engage with potential new PRIF members and new 
member countries (ongoing). 
1.12  Facilitate information sharing and peer reviews between PRIF partners, and among other relevant 
stakeholders, regional organizations, and sector interest groups (ongoing). 
1.13  Facilitate the preparation of sector profiles for two member countries, outlining the activities of 
PRIF partners and other regional organizations in each sector, in consultation with sector working groups 
(by October 2020). 
 
2.  Technical advice on infrastructure development and sustainable infrastructure 
management provided to PRIF partners and member countries 
2.1  Sign short-term framework agreements with technical specialist consultants covering the range of 
sectors and crosscutting themes (by December 2019). 
2.2  Assist member countries in preparing national infrastructure development plans and/or asset 
management plans on demand and in consultation with sector working groups (by October 2023). 
2.3  Support and facilitate ongoing tracking of actual country and regional programs of PRIF partners 
against the infrastructure plans, in coordination with PRIF partners headquarters and posts (by October 
2023). 
2.4  Assist member countries in preparing sector development plans on demand and in consultation 
with sector working groups (by October 2023). 
2.5  Provide short-term technical advice using specialist technical advisors and technical specialists 
from the PRIF sector working groups, as requested by PRIF partners, member countries and regional 
organizations (by October 2023). 
2.6  Develop knowledge products and technical reports per annum in close coordination with PRIF 
partners, member countries, sector working groups, and regional organizations (by October 2023). 
2.7  Consult with PRIF partners and other relevant organizations to include strategic themes in the 
first annual work plan for management committee approval (by October 2023). 
2.8  Maintain and expand the document library on the PRIF website (by October 2023). 
2.9  Implement a quality assurance process for PRIF TA outputs, including liaison with sector lead 
coordinators and working group members, and independent review by short-term specialist consultants 
(by October 2020). 
2.10  Prepare a monitoring and evaluation plan consistent with the TA project’s design and monitoring 
framework for management committee approval (by December 2019). 
2.11  Report quarterly and annually on progress against the monitoring and evaluation plan. 
2.12  Liaise with government counterparts of PRIF partners, member countries and regional 
organizations, and on proposals for assistance on demand (ongoing). 
 
TA Management Activities 
Allocate ADB project officer, allocate time for sector working and management committee representation 
by ADB staff, and allocate office space within ADB’s Pacific Liaison and Coordination Office.
